content: The Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 establishes privacy officials within each component of the Department of Homeland Security. The Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 mandates the designation of full-time privacy officials for specific components of the Department, including the Transportation Security Administration, Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services, Customs and Border Protection, and Immigration and Customs Enforcement. These officials report directly to the senior official appointed under section 222 and are responsible for implementing the Department's privacy policy. The Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 requires full-time privacy officials for specific components like Immigration and Customs Enforcement, FEMA, Coast Guard, and others. These officials report to the senior official appointed under section 222 and are responsible for implementing privacy policies within their component. The Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 mandates privacy officials for specific components to advise on privacy considerations, ensure technology use enhances privacy protections, identify and address privacy issues, and monitor compliance with Federal privacy laws and regulations. The Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 mandates privacy officials to advise on privacy considerations, ensure technology enhances privacy protections, address privacy issues, and monitor compliance with Federal privacy laws. They must also handle personal information in compliance with the Privacy Act and assist in drafting privacy impact assessments for new programs or technologies collecting personally identifiable information. The Department of Homeland Security Component Privacy Officer Act of 2008 mandates privacy officials to advise on privacy considerations, ensure technology enhances privacy protections, address privacy issues, and monitor compliance with Federal privacy laws. They must also handle personal information in compliance with the Privacy Act and assist in drafting privacy impact assessments for new programs or technologies collecting personally identifiable information. The senior official appointed under section 222 is responsible for conducting supervision of programs, regulations, policies, procedures, or guidelines to ensure the component's protection of privacy, implementing and monitoring privacy training for employees and contractors, and providing written materials and information regarding relevant activities of the component to ensure privacy protection. The head of a component identified in subsection (a)(2) must ensure that the privacy official designated for that component has the necessary resources to fulfill their responsibilities, is involved in decision-making processes for policy changes and new programs, and is provided with information on relevant activities of the component. The privacy official designated for a component must have access to necessary resources and personnel for their responsibilities, including involvement in decision-making processes. This section does not diminish the role of the senior official appointed under section 222. "Sec. 222A. Privacy officials. Passed the House of Representatives July 30, 2008. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk."
